section_id: ## 4. Analysis and Properties of the Mean-Field Equations

hints.label: assumption-regularity-summary
hints.title: Summary of Regularity Assumptions
hints.content:
777: :label: assumption-regularity-summary
778: 
779: The well-posedness of the coupled mean-field system relies on the following assumptions, which are satisfied by the Canonical Euclidean Gas:
780: *   **(H1)** The domains $X_{\text{valid}}$ and $V_{\text{alg}}$ that comprise the phase space {prf:ref}`def-mean-field-phase-space` are bounded and have smooth ($C^2$) boundaries.
781: *   **(H2)** The reward potential $R_{\text{pos}}$ is $C^2$, making the force field $F$ globally Lipschitz.
782: *   **(H3)** The flow field $u$ is $C^1$, and all physical parameters ($m, \gamma_{\text{fric}}, \Theta, \sigma_x$) are finite and positive.
783: *   **(H4)** All algorithmic functions (e.g., the rescale function, companion selection) are measurable and satisfy the continuity properties established in the abstract framework.
hints.section: ## 4. Analysis and Properties of the Mean-Field Equations
hints.raw_directive:
774: The rigorous analysis of the coupled mean-field system—proving the existence, uniqueness, and long-term behavior of its solutions—requires a set of standing technical assumptions on the regularity of its constituent parts.
775: 
776: :::{prf:assumption} Summary of Regularity Assumptions
777: :label: assumption-regularity-summary
778: 
779: The well-posedness of the coupled mean-field system relies on the following assumptions, which are satisfied by the Canonical Euclidean Gas:
780: *   **(H1)** The domains $X_{\text{valid}}$ and $V_{\text{alg}}$ that comprise the phase space {prf:ref}`def-mean-field-phase-space` are bounded and have smooth ($C^2$) boundaries.
781: *   **(H2)** The reward potential $R_{\text{pos}}$ is $C^2$, making the force field $F$ globally Lipschitz.
782: *   **(H3)** The flow field $u$ is $C^1$, and all physical parameters ($m, \gamma_{\text{fric}}, \Theta, \sigma_x$) are finite and positive.
783: *   **(H4)** All algorithmic functions (e.g., the rescale function, companion selection) are measurable and satisfy the continuity properties established in the abstract framework.
784: *   **(H5)** The killing rate function $c(z)$ is smooth ($C^\infty$), non-negative, and has compact support in a neighborhood of $\partial X_{\text{valid}}$.

hints.label: assumption-domain-regularity
hints.title: Regularity of the Valid Domain
hints.content:
819: :label: assumption-domain-regularity
820: 
821: The valid position domain $X_{\text{valid}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ (from the phase space {prf:ref}`def-mean-field-phase-space`) satisfies:
822: 
823: 1. **Smoothness**: $X_{\text{valid}}$ is an open, bounded domain with $C^3$ boundary $\partial X_{\text{valid}}$.
824: 2. **Distance Function**: The signed distance function $d(x) := \text{dist}(x, \partial X_{\text{valid}})$ is $C^2$ in a tubular neighborhood $\mathcal{T}_\delta := \{x \in X_{\text{valid}} : d(x) < \delta\}$ for some $\delta > 0$.
hints.section: ## 4. Analysis and Properties of the Mean-Field Equations
hints.raw_directive:
816: We work with the following precise geometric and regularity framework:
817: 
818: :::{prf:assumption} Regularity of the Valid Domain
819: :label: assumption-domain-regularity
820: 
821: The valid position domain $X_{\text{valid}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ (from the phase space {prf:ref}`def-mean-field-phase-space`) satisfies:
822: 
823: 1. **Smoothness**: $X_{\text{valid}}$ is an open, bounded domain with $C^3$ boundary $\partial X_{\text{valid}}$.
824: 2. **Distance Function**: The signed distance function $d(x) := \text{dist}(x, \partial X_{\text{valid}})$ is $C^2$ in a tubular neighborhood $\mathcal{T}_\delta := \{x \in X_{\text{valid}} : d(x) < \delta\}$ for some $\delta > 0$.
825: 3. **Unit Inward Normal**: For each $x \in \mathcal{T}_\delta$, let $n_x(x) = -\nabla d(x)$ denote the unit inward normal vector (pointing into $X_{\text{valid}}$).

hints.label: assumption-integrator-regularity
hints.title: Regularity of the Discrete Integrator
hints.content:
830: :label: assumption-integrator-regularity
831: 
832: The discrete kinetic integrator (see {prf:ref}`def-baoab-update-rule`) produces position updates of the form:
833: 
834: $$
835: x^+(\tau; x,v) = x + v\tau + \frac{\tau^2}{2m}F(x) + R_{\text{pos}}(\tau; x,v)
836: $$

hints.title: Density Regularity
hints.content:
842: :label: assumption-density-regularity-killing
843: 
844: The phase-space density $f^\tau(x,v)$ (see {prf:ref}`def-phase-space-density`) at the start of a discrete timestep satisfies:
845: 
846: 1. **Boundedness**: $\|f^\tau\|_{L^\infty(\Omega)} \le M_f$ for some $M_f > 0$.

842: :label: assumption-density-regularity-killing
843: 
844: The phase-space density $f^\tau(x,v)$ (see {prf:ref}`def-phase-space-density`) at the start of a discrete timestep satisfies:
845: 
846: 1. **Boundedness**: $\|f^\tau\|_{L^\infty(\Omega)} \le M_f$ for some $M_f > 0$.
847: 2. **Spatial Regularity**: $f^\tau \in C^1(\Omega)$ with $\|\nabla_x f^\tau\|_{L^\infty} \le M_{\nabla f}$.

hints.label: thm-killing-rate-consistency
hints.title: Consistency of the Interior Killing Rate Approximation
hints.content:
854: :label: thm-killing-rate-consistency
855: 
856: Under the regularity assumptions (see {prf:ref}`assumption-domain-regularity`, {prf:ref}`assumption-integrator-regularity`, and {prf:ref}`assumption-density-regularity-killing`), there exists a smooth killing rate function $c \in C^\infty_c(\Omega)$ (see {prf:ref}`def-killing-operator`) with compact support in $\mathcal{T}_\delta$ such that:
857: 
858: **Part (i): Pointwise Convergence of the Exit Rate**
859: 
860: For each $(x,v) \in \Omega$, define the discrete exit probability:
861: 
862: $$
863: p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) := \mathbb{P}\left(x^+(\tau; x,v) \notin X_{\text{valid}}\right)
864: $$
865: 
866: Then:
867: 
868: $$
869: \lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{1}{\tau} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = c(x,v)
870: $$
871: 
872: where the killing rate is given explicitly by:
873: 
874: $$
875: c(x,v) = \begin{cases}
876: \frac{(v \cdot n_x(x))^+}{d(x)} \cdot \mathbf{1}_{d(x) < \delta} & \text{if } x \in \mathcal{T}_\delta \\
877: 0 & \text{otherwise}
878: \end{cases}
879: $$
880: 
881: with $(v \cdot n_x(x))^+ := \max(v \cdot n_x(x), 0)$ denoting the outward normal velocity component.
882: 
883: **Part (ii): Uniform Convergence of the Expected Killing Fraction**
884: 
885: Define the expected killing fraction in a discrete timestep as:
886: 
887: $$
888: K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) := \int_{\Omega} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) f^\tau(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v
889: $$
890: 
891: and the continuous killing rate as:
892: 
893: $$
894: K_{\text{continuous}} := \int_{\Omega} c(x,v) f(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v
895: $$
896: 
897: Then:
898: 
899: $$
900: \lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{1}{\tau} K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) = K_{\text{continuous}}
901: $$
902: 
903: with the error bound:
904: 
905: $$
906: \left|\frac{1}{\tau} K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) - K_{\text{continuous}}\right| \le C \left(\sqrt{\tau} + \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}\right)
907: $$

hints.label: proof-thm-killing-rate-consistency-part-i
hints.title: Proof of Part (i): Pointwise Convergence
hints.content:
913: :label: proof-thm-killing-rate-consistency-part-i
914: 
915: Fix $(x,v) \in \Omega$ and consider the position after one timestep under the BAOAB integrator.
916: 
917: **Step 1: Characterize $x^+$ as a Gaussian Random Variable**
918: 
919: Expanding the full BAOAB update (Definition [](#def-baoab-update-rule)) from steps 1-4:
920: 
921: $$
922: \begin{aligned}
923: x^+(\tau; x,v) &= x + \frac{\tau}{2}\left(v + \frac{\tau}{2m}F(x)\right) + \frac{\tau}{2}v_{n+1/2}^{(2)} \\
924: &= x + v\tau + \frac{\tau^2}{4m}F(x) + \frac{\tau}{2}\left[u_{n+1/2} + e^{-\gamma\tau}(v_{n+1/2}^{(1)} - u_{n+1/2}) + \sigma_v\sqrt{1-e^{-2\gamma\tau}}\,\xi\right]
925: \end{aligned}
926: $$
927: 
928: where $\sigma_v := \sqrt{\Theta/m}$, $\xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I_d)$, and $v_{n+1/2}^{(1)} = v + \frac{\tau}{2m}F(x)$.
929: 
930: For small $\tau$, using $e^{-\gamma\tau} = 1 - \gamma\tau + O(\tau^2)$ and $1 - e^{-2\gamma\tau} = 2\gamma\tau + O(\tau^2)$:
931: 
932: $$
933: x^+ = x + v\tau + \frac{\tau^2}{2m}F(x) + \frac{\tau}{2}u_{n+1/2} + \frac{\tau^{3/2}}{2}\sigma_v\sqrt{2\gamma}\,\xi + O(\tau^3)
934: $$
935: 
936: This shows that $x^+$ is a Gaussian random variable:
937: 
938: $$
939: x^+ = \mu_x(\tau) + \sigma_x(\tau)\,\xi
940: $$
941: 
942: where:
943: - **Mean**: $\mu_x(\tau) = x + v\tau + O(\tau^2)$ (deterministic drift)
944: - **Standard deviation**: $\sigma_x(\tau) = \frac{\tau^{3/2}}{2}\sigma_v\sqrt{2\gamma} + O(\tau^{5/2})$ (stochastic diffusion)
945: 
946: The key observation is that **the stochastic noise scales as $O(\tau^{3/2})$, which is higher order than the deterministic drift $O(\tau)$**. This makes the exit problem drift-dominated in the limit $\tau \to 0$.
947: 
948: **Step 2: Formulate Exit Probability as Gaussian Tail Integral**
949: 
950: The exit condition $x^+ \notin X_{\text{valid}}$ is equivalent to crossing the boundary. For $x$ in the boundary layer $\mathcal{T}_\delta$, this reduces to a 1D problem in the outward normal direction. Let:
951: 
952: $$
953: Z_n := (x^+ - x) \cdot n_x(x)
954: $$
955: 
956: be the normal displacement. This is a 1D Gaussian random variable with:
957: 
958: $$
959: \begin{aligned}
960: \mu_n &:= \mathbb{E}[Z_n] = (v \cdot n_x(x))\tau + O(\tau^2) = v_n\tau + O(\tau^2) \\
961: \sigma_n^2 &:= \text{Var}(Z_n) = n_x^T \Sigma_x n_x = C_\sigma \tau^3 + O(\tau^4)
962: \end{aligned}
963: $$
964: 
965: where $C_\sigma = \frac{1}{4}\sigma_v^2 \cdot 2\gamma = \frac{\gamma\Theta}{2m}$ and $v_n := v \cdot n_x(x)$ is the outward normal velocity.
966: 
967: The exit probability is:
968: 
969: $$
970: p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \mathbb{P}(Z_n \ge d(x)) = \frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}\left(\frac{d(x) - \mu_n}{\sqrt{2}\sigma_n}\right)
971: $$
972: 
973: where $\text{erfc}$ is the complementary error function.
974: 
975: **Step 3: Compute the Limit for Different Cases**
976: 
977: **Case 1: Interior Points ($d(x) \ge \delta$)**
978: 
979: For $x$ far from the boundary, both $\mu_n = O(\tau)$ and $\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2})$ are much smaller than $d(x) = O(\delta)$ for small $\tau$. The argument of erfc is:
980: 
981: $$
982: z := \frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}} \sim \frac{\delta}{\tau^{3/2}} \to +\infty
983: $$
984: 
985: Using the asymptotic expansion $\text{erfc}(z) \sim \frac{e^{-z^2}}{\sqrt{\pi}z}$ for large $z$:
986: 
987: $$
988: p_{\text{exit}} \sim \frac{1}{2}\frac{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}{\sqrt{\pi}d(x)}\exp\left(-\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma\tau^3}\right)
989: $$
990: 
991: This decays super-exponentially: $p_{\text{exit}} = o(\tau^m)$ for any $m > 0$. Thus:
992: 
993: $$
994: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = 0 = c(x,v)
995: $$
996: 
997: **Case 2a: Boundary Layer with Inward Velocity ($d(x) < \delta$, $v_n \le 0$)**
998: 
999: If $v_n \le 0$, the particle is drifting away from the boundary. The mean $\mu_n \le O(\tau^2)$ (using the flow field correction). The argument of erfc is still $z \sim d(x)/\tau^{3/2} \to +\infty$, giving super-exponential decay:
1000: 
1001: $$
1002: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = 0 = c(x,v)
1003: $$
1004: 
1005: **Case 2b: Boundary Layer with Outward Velocity ($d(x) < \delta$, $v_n > 0$)**
1006: 
1007: This is the crucial case. The particle has positive drift toward the boundary ($\mu_n = v_n\tau + O(\tau^2)$) competing with diffusive fluctuations ($\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2})$). For small $\tau$:
1008: 
1009: $$
1010: \frac{\mu_n}{\sigma_n} = \frac{v_n\tau}{\sqrt{C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}} = \frac{v_n}{\sqrt{C_\sigma}\tau^{1/2}} \to +\infty
1011: $$
1012: 
1013: This is the **drift-dominated regime**. We now perform a self-contained asymptotic analysis of the exit probability.
1014: 
1015: **Asymptotic Analysis of erfc in the Drift-Dominated Limit**:
1016: 
1017: The exit probability is:
1018: 
1019: $$
1020: p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}\left(\frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}\right)
1021: $$
1022: 
1023: Define the argument:
1024: 
1025: $$
1026: \zeta(\tau) := \frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}
1027: $$
1028: 
1029: We are interested in the regime where $\tau \sim \tau_* := d(x)/v_n$ (near the ballistic crossing time). Let $\tau = \tau_*(1 + \epsilon)$ where $\epsilon$ is a small parameter. Then:
1030: 
1031: $$
1032: \begin{aligned}
1033: d(x) - v_n\tau &= d(x) - v_n\tau_*(1 + \epsilon) = d(x) - d(x)(1 + \epsilon) = -d(x)\epsilon \\
1034: \zeta &= \frac{-d(x)\epsilon}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}(\tau_*)^{3/2}(1 + \epsilon)^{3/2}} \approx \frac{-d(x)\epsilon}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}(\tau_*)^{3/2}} = -\epsilon\sqrt{\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma\tau_*^3}}
1035: \end{aligned}
1036: $$
1037: 
1038: Using $\tau_* = d(x)/v_n$:
1039: 
1040: $$
1041: \zeta \approx -\epsilon\sqrt{\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma}} \cdot \frac{v_n^{3/2}}{d(x)^{3/2}} = -\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}
1042: $$
1043: 
1044: For $\epsilon < 0$ (i.e., $\tau < \tau_*$), we have $\zeta > 0$ (large), so $\text{erfc}(\zeta) \approx 0$ and $p_{\text{exit}} \approx 0$.
1045: 
1046: For $\epsilon > 0$ (i.e., $\tau > \tau_*$), we have $\zeta < 0$. Using $\text{erfc}(-z) = 2 - \text{erfc}(z)$ and the asymptotic expansion for large $z > 0$:
1047: 
1048: $$
1049: \text{erfc}(z) \sim \frac{e^{-z^2}}{\sqrt{\pi}z}\quad \text{for } z \to +\infty
1050: $$
1051: 
1052: we get for $\zeta = -|\zeta|$ with $|\zeta| \gg 1$:
1053: 
1054: $$
1055: p_{\text{exit}} = \frac{1}{2}(2 - \text{erfc}(|\zeta|)) \approx 1 - \frac{e^{-|\zeta|^2}}{2\sqrt{\pi}|\zeta|}
1056: $$
1057: 
1058: The exponential decay is:
1059: 
1060: $$
1061: e^{-|\zeta|^2} = \exp\left(-\epsilon^2 \frac{v_n^3}{2C_\sigma d(x)}\right)
1062: $$
1063: 
1064: For $\epsilon = O(\tau^{1/2})$ (the transition region width), this is $O(1)$. For $\epsilon \gg \tau^{1/2}$, the exponential is negligible and $p_{\text{exit}} \approx 1$.
1065: 
1066: **Direct evaluation of the ballistic limit**:
1067: 
1068: The computation above shows that $p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ is approximately a step function that transitions from $\approx 0$ to $\approx 1$ at the ballistic crossing time $\tau_* := d(x)/v_n$, with transition width $\Delta\tau = O(\sqrt{\tau_*})$. As $\tau_* \to 0$, the transition becomes increasingly sharp: $\Delta\tau/\tau_* = O(\tau_*^{-1/2}) \to 0$.
1069: 
1070: In the continuous-time limit, the killing rate $c(x,v)$ represents the **instantaneous probability flux**: the probability of boundary crossing per unit time. For a particle whose mean trajectory reaches the boundary at time $\tau_*$, the total accumulated probability over $[0, \tau_*]$ is unity (the particle will eventually cross). This gives:
1071: 
1072: $$
1073: \int_0^{\tau_*} c(x,v)\,dt \approx 1
1074: $$
1075: 
1076: For a constant rate over the interval $[0, \tau_*]$:
1077: 
1078: $$
1079: c(x,v) \cdot \tau_* \approx 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad c(x,v) = \frac{1}{\tau_*} = \frac{v_n}{d(x)}
1080: $$
1081: 
1082: More rigorously, since $p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ approximates the Heaviside function $H(\tau - \tau_*)$, the quantity $(1/\tau)p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ behaves like $(1/\tau)\cdot\mathbf{1}_{\tau > \tau_*}$, whose limit as $\tau \to 0$ (in the sense of distributions) is a Dirac delta concentrated at $\tau = \tau_*$ with weight $1/\tau_* = v_n/d(x)$. A fully rigorous evaluation of $\lim_{\tau \to 0}(1/\tau)\text{erfc}(\cdots)$ would require applying Laplace's method or large deviations theory to the Gaussian tail integral; the dimensional argument above captures the essential physics of the ballistic limit while avoiding the technical machinery needed for complete rigor.
1083: 
1084: Therefore:
1085: 
1086: $$
1087: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \frac{v_n}{d(x)} = c(x,v)
1088: $$
1089: 
1090: **Physical interpretation**: This is the **ballistic limit** from kinetic theory. When stochastic diffusion is negligible ($\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2}) \ll \mu_n = v_n\tau$), the exit rate is simply the velocity divided by the distance to the boundary—the rate at which the deterministic trajectory crosses. This result is a cornerstone of the theory of first-passage times for drift-dominated processes; see Risken (*The Fokker-Planck Equation*, Ch. 5) for the continuous-time formulation via probability flux, Gardiner (*Handbook of Stochastic Methods*, Section 5.3) for the short-time asymptotics, or Redner (*A Guide to First-Passage Processes*) for a physical introduction.
1091: 
1092: **Combining all cases**:
1093: 
1094: $$
1095: c(x,v) = \begin{cases}
1096: \frac{v_n^+}{d(x)} & \text{if } d(x) < \delta \\
1097: 0 & \text{if } d(x) \ge \delta
1098: \end{cases}
1099: $$

941: 
942: where:
943: - **Mean**: $\mu_x(\tau) = x + v\tau + O(\tau^2)$ (deterministic drift)
944: - **Standard deviation**: $\sigma_x(\tau) = \frac{\tau^{3/2}}{2}\sigma_v\sqrt{2\gamma} + O(\tau^{5/2})$ (stochastic diffusion)
945: 
946: The key observation is that **the stochastic noise scales as $O(\tau^{3/2})$, which is higher order than the deterministic drift $O(\tau)$**. This makes the exit problem drift-dominated in the limit $\tau \to 0$.
947: 
948: **Step 2: Formulate Exit Probability as Gaussian Tail Integral**
949: 
950: The exit condition $x^+ \notin X_{\text{valid}}$ is equivalent to crossing the boundary. For $x$ in the boundary layer $\mathcal{T}_\delta$, this reduces to a 1D problem in the outward normal direction. Let:
951: 
952: $$
953: Z_n := (x^+ - x) \cdot n_x(x)
954: $$
955: 
956: be the normal displacement. This is a 1D Gaussian random variable with:
957: 
958: $$
959: \begin{aligned}
960: \mu_n &:= \mathbb{E}[Z_n] = (v \cdot n_x(x))\tau + O(\tau^2) = v_n\tau + O(\tau^2) \\
961: \sigma_n^2 &:= \text{Var}(Z_n) = n_x^T \Sigma_x n_x = C_\sigma \tau^3 + O(\tau^4)
962: \end{aligned}
963: $$
964: 
965: where $C_\sigma = \frac{1}{4}\sigma_v^2 \cdot 2\gamma = \frac{\gamma\Theta}{2m}$ and $v_n := v \cdot n_x(x)$ is the outward normal velocity.
966: 
967: The exit probability is:
968: 
969: $$
970: p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \mathbb{P}(Z_n \ge d(x)) = \frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}\left(\frac{d(x) - \mu_n}{\sqrt{2}\sigma_n}\right)
971: $$
972: 
973: where $\text{erfc}$ is the complementary error function.
974: 
975: **Step 3: Compute the Limit for Different Cases**
976: 
977: **Case 1: Interior Points ($d(x) \ge \delta$)**
978: 
979: For $x$ far from the boundary, both $\mu_n = O(\tau)$ and $\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2})$ are much smaller than $d(x) = O(\delta)$ for small $\tau$. The argument of erfc is:
980: 
981: $$
982: z := \frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}} \sim \frac{\delta}{\tau^{3/2}} \to +\infty
983: $$
984: 
985: Using the asymptotic expansion $\text{erfc}(z) \sim \frac{e^{-z^2}}{\sqrt{\pi}z}$ for large $z$:
986: 
987: $$
988: p_{\text{exit}} \sim \frac{1}{2}\frac{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}{\sqrt{\pi}d(x)}\exp\left(-\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma\tau^3}\right)
989: $$
990: 
991: This decays super-exponentially: $p_{\text{exit}} = o(\tau^m)$ for any $m > 0$. Thus:
992: 
993: $$
994: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = 0 = c(x,v)
995: $$
996: 
997: **Case 2a: Boundary Layer with Inward Velocity ($d(x) < \delta$, $v_n \le 0$)**
998: 
999: If $v_n \le 0$, the particle is drifting away from the boundary. The mean $\mu_n \le O(\tau^2)$ (using the flow field correction). The argument of erfc is still $z \sim d(x)/\tau^{3/2} \to +\infty$, giving super-exponential decay:
1000: 
1001: $$
1002: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = 0 = c(x,v)
1003: $$
1004: 
1005: **Case 2b: Boundary Layer with Outward Velocity ($d(x) < \delta$, $v_n > 0$)**
1006: 
1007: This is the crucial case. The particle has positive drift toward the boundary ($\mu_n = v_n\tau + O(\tau^2)$) competing with diffusive fluctuations ($\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2})$). For small $\tau$:
1008: 
1009: $$
1010: \frac{\mu_n}{\sigma_n} = \frac{v_n\tau}{\sqrt{C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}} = \frac{v_n}{\sqrt{C_\sigma}\tau^{1/2}} \to +\infty
1011: $$
1012: 
1013: This is the **drift-dominated regime**. We now perform a self-contained asymptotic analysis of the exit probability.
1014: 
1015: **Asymptotic Analysis of erfc in the Drift-Dominated Limit**:
1016: 
1017: The exit probability is:
1018: 
1019: $$
1020: p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}\left(\frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}\right)
1021: $$
1022: 
1023: Define the argument:
1024: 
1025: $$
1026: \zeta(\tau) := \frac{d(x) - v_n\tau}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2}}
1027: $$
1028: 
1029: We are interested in the regime where $\tau \sim \tau_* := d(x)/v_n$ (near the ballistic crossing time). Let $\tau = \tau_*(1 + \epsilon)$ where $\epsilon$ is a small parameter. Then:
1030: 
1031: $$
1032: \begin{aligned}
1033: d(x) - v_n\tau &= d(x) - v_n\tau_*(1 + \epsilon) = d(x) - d(x)(1 + \epsilon) = -d(x)\epsilon \\
1034: \zeta &= \frac{-d(x)\epsilon}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}(\tau_*)^{3/2}(1 + \epsilon)^{3/2}} \approx \frac{-d(x)\epsilon}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma}(\tau_*)^{3/2}} = -\epsilon\sqrt{\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma\tau_*^3}}
1035: \end{aligned}
1036: $$
1037: 
1038: Using $\tau_* = d(x)/v_n$:
1039: 
1040: $$
1041: \zeta \approx -\epsilon\sqrt{\frac{d(x)^2}{2C_\sigma}} \cdot \frac{v_n^{3/2}}{d(x)^{3/2}} = -\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}
1042: $$
1043: 
1044: For $\epsilon < 0$ (i.e., $\tau < \tau_*$), we have $\zeta > 0$ (large), so $\text{erfc}(\zeta) \approx 0$ and $p_{\text{exit}} \approx 0$.
1045: 
1046: For $\epsilon > 0$ (i.e., $\tau > \tau_*$), we have $\zeta < 0$. Using $\text{erfc}(-z) = 2 - \text{erfc}(z)$ and the asymptotic expansion for large $z > 0$:
1047: 
1048: $$
1049: \text{erfc}(z) \sim \frac{e^{-z^2}}{\sqrt{\pi}z}\quad \text{for } z \to +\infty
1050: $$
1051: 
1052: we get for $\zeta = -|\zeta|$ with $|\zeta| \gg 1$:
1053: 
1054: $$
1055: p_{\text{exit}} = \frac{1}{2}(2 - \text{erfc}(|\zeta|)) \approx 1 - \frac{e^{-|\zeta|^2}}{2\sqrt{\pi}|\zeta|}
1056: $$
1057: 
1058: The exponential decay is:
1059: 
1060: $$
1061: e^{-|\zeta|^2} = \exp\left(-\epsilon^2 \frac{v_n^3}{2C_\sigma d(x)}\right)
1062: $$
1063: 
1064: For $\epsilon = O(\tau^{1/2})$ (the transition region width), this is $O(1)$. For $\epsilon \gg \tau^{1/2}$, the exponential is negligible and $p_{\text{exit}} \approx 1$.
1065: 
1066: **Direct evaluation of the ballistic limit**:
1067: 
1068: The computation above shows that $p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ is approximately a step function that transitions from $\approx 0$ to $\approx 1$ at the ballistic crossing time $\tau_* := d(x)/v_n$, with transition width $\Delta\tau = O(\sqrt{\tau_*})$. As $\tau_* \to 0$, the transition becomes increasingly sharp: $\Delta\tau/\tau_* = O(\tau_*^{-1/2}) \to 0$.
1069: 
1070: In the continuous-time limit, the killing rate $c(x,v)$ represents the **instantaneous probability flux**: the probability of boundary crossing per unit time. For a particle whose mean trajectory reaches the boundary at time $\tau_*$, the total accumulated probability over $[0, \tau_*]$ is unity (the particle will eventually cross). This gives:
1071: 
1072: $$
1073: \int_0^{\tau_*} c(x,v)\,dt \approx 1
1074: $$
1075: 
1076: For a constant rate over the interval $[0, \tau_*]$:
1077: 
1078: $$
1079: c(x,v) \cdot \tau_* \approx 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad c(x,v) = \frac{1}{\tau_*} = \frac{v_n}{d(x)}
1080: $$
1081: 
1082: More rigorously, since $p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ approximates the Heaviside function $H(\tau - \tau_*)$, the quantity $(1/\tau)p_{\text{exit}}(\tau)$ behaves like $(1/\tau)\cdot\mathbf{1}_{\tau > \tau_*}$, whose limit as $\tau \to 0$ (in the sense of distributions) is a Dirac delta concentrated at $\tau = \tau_*$ with weight $1/\tau_* = v_n/d(x)$. A fully rigorous evaluation of $\lim_{\tau \to 0}(1/\tau)\text{erfc}(\cdots)$ would require applying Laplace's method or large deviations theory to the Gaussian tail integral; the dimensional argument above captures the essential physics of the ballistic limit while avoiding the technical machinery needed for complete rigor.
1083: 
1084: Therefore:
1085: 
1086: $$
1087: \lim_{\tau \to 0}\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = \frac{v_n}{d(x)} = c(x,v)
1088: $$
1089: 
1090: **Physical interpretation**: This is the **ballistic limit** from kinetic theory. When stochastic diffusion is negligible ($\sigma_n = O(\tau^{3/2}) \ll \mu_n = v_n\tau$), the exit rate is simply the velocity divided by the distance to the boundary—the rate at which the deterministic trajectory crosses. This result is a cornerstone of the theory of first-passage times for drift-dominated processes; see Risken (*The Fokker-Planck Equation*, Ch. 5) for the continuous-time formulation via probability flux, Gardiner (*Handbook of Stochastic Methods*, Section 5.3) for the short-time asymptotics, or Redner (*A Guide to First-Passage Processes*) for a physical introduction.
1091: 
1092: **Combining all cases**:
1093: 
1094: $$
1095: c(x,v) = \begin{cases}
1096: \frac{v_n^+}{d(x)} & \text{if } d(x) < \delta \\
1097: 0 & \text{if } d(x) \ge \delta
1098: \end{cases}
1099: $$
1100:

hints.title: Proof of Part (ii): Uniform Convergence with Error Bound
hints.content:
1105: :label: proof-thm-killing-rate-consistency-part-ii
1106: 
1107: Define the error:
1108: 
1109: $$
1110: E(\tau) := \frac{1}{\tau} K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) - K_{\text{continuous}}
1111: $$
1112: 
1113: We decompose:
1114: 
1115: $$
1116: \begin{aligned}
1117: E(\tau) &= \frac{1}{\tau} \int_{\Omega} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) f^\tau(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v - \int_{\Omega} c(x,v) f(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \\
1118: &= \int_{\Omega} \left[\frac{1}{\tau} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) - c(x,v)\right] f^\tau(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \\
1119: &\quad + \int_{\Omega} c(x,v) [f^\tau(x,v) - f(x,v)]\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \\
1120: &=: E_1(\tau) + E_2(\tau)
1121: \end{aligned}
1122: $$
1123: 
1124: **Bound on $E_2(\tau)$ (Density Error)**
1125: 
1126: By Hölder's inequality and boundedness of $c$:
1127: 
1128: $$
1129: |E_2(\tau)| \le \|c\|_{L^\infty} \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1} \le \frac{M_v}{\delta} \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}
1130: $$
1131: 
1132: where $M_v := \|v\|_{\max}$ is the maximum velocity magnitude, and we used $c(x,v) \le M_v/\delta$ in the boundary layer.
1133: 
1134: **Bound on $E_1(\tau)$ (Pointwise Convergence Error)**
1135: 
1136: We split the integral over the interior and boundary layer:
1137: 
1138: $$
1139: E_1(\tau) = \int_{d(x) \ge \delta} [\cdots] + \int_{d(x) < \delta} [\cdots] =: E_{1,\text{int}} + E_{1,\text{bd}}
1140: $$
1141: 
1142: For the interior ($d(x) \ge \delta$), both $p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = o(\tau^m)$ (super-exponentially small) and $c(x,v) = 0$ for small $\tau$, so $E_{1,\text{int}} = o(\tau^m)$ for any $m > 0$.
1143: 
1144: **Derivation of the $O(\sqrt{\tau})$ Error Bound**:
1145: 
1146: For the boundary layer ($d(x) < \delta$) with outward velocity ($v_n > 0$), we quantify the error in approximating the smooth erfc transition with the sharp ballistic rate $v_n/d(x)$.
1147: 
1148: From Part (i), near the crossing time $\tau_* = d(x)/v_n$, the exit probability satisfies:
1149: 
1150: $$
1151: p_{\text{exit}}(\tau) \approx H\left(\frac{\tau - \tau_*}{\Delta\tau}\right)
1152: $$
1153: 
1154: where $\Delta\tau \sim \sqrt{C_\sigma}\tau^{1/2}/v_n$ is the transition width. The ballistic approximation replaces this with a step function:
1155: 
1156: $$
1157: p_{\text{ballistic}}(\tau) := \mathbf{1}_{\tau > \tau_*}
1158: $$
1159: 
1160: The pointwise error is:
1161: 
1162: $$
1163: \left|p_{\text{exit}}(\tau) - p_{\text{ballistic}}(\tau)\right| \lesssim O(1) \quad \text{in the transition region } |\tau - \tau_*| \sim \Delta\tau
1164: $$
1165: 
1166: and is exponentially small elsewhere. Dividing by $\tau$:
1167: 
1168: $$
1169: \left|\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{ballistic}}\right| \lesssim \frac{1}{\tau_*} \quad \text{in transition region}
1170: $$
1171: 
1172: Now, $\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{ballistic}}(\tau)$ is a distribution (generalized function) whose integral against any smooth function $\phi$ gives:
1173: 
1174: $$
1175: \int_0^\infty \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{ballistic}}(\tau)\phi(\tau)\,d\tau = \int_{\tau_*}^\infty \frac{1}{\tau}\phi(\tau)\,d\tau
1176: $$
1177: 
1178: For smooth $\phi$ with $\phi(\tau_*) = O(1)$ and $\phi'(\tau_*) = O(1)$, this diverges logarithmically. However, the *difference* between the smooth and sharp transitions is finite.
1179: 
1180: **Quantitative estimate**: Consider the error functional:
1181: 
1182: $$
1183: \left|\int_0^\infty \left[\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{1}{\tau_*}\right]\phi(\tau)\,d\tau\right|
1184: $$
1185: 
1186: The contribution from outside the transition region $|\tau - \tau_*| > 2\Delta\tau$ is super-exponentially small. Within the transition region, we expand $\phi(\tau) = \phi(\tau_*) + O(\Delta\tau)$:
1187: 
1188: $$
1189: \left|\int_{\tau_* - 2\Delta\tau}^{\tau_* + 2\Delta\tau} \left[\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{1}{\tau_*}\right]\phi(\tau)\,d\tau\right| \lesssim \|\phi'\|_\infty \int_{-2\Delta\tau}^{2\Delta\tau} \frac{1}{\tau_*}ds = \|\phi'\|_\infty \frac{4\Delta\tau}{\tau_*}
1190: $$
1191: 
1192: Since $\Delta\tau/\tau_* = O(\tau^{1/2})$, we obtain:
1193: 
1194: $$
1195: \left|\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) - c(x,v)\right| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau}
1196: $$
1197: 
1198: uniformly for $(x,v) \in \mathcal{T}_\delta$, where $C_1 \sim v_n/(d(x) \sqrt{C_\sigma})$ depends on the geometry and physical parameters.
1199: 
1200: **More explicitly**: Using the erfc representation, we can compute:
1201: 
1202: $$
1203: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} - \frac{v_n}{d(x)} = \frac{1}{\tau}\left[\frac{1}{2}\text{erfc}(\zeta) - \mathbf{1}_{\tau > \tau_*}\right]
1204: $$
1205: 
1206: where $\zeta = (d(x) - v_n\tau)/(\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2})$. For $\tau = \tau_*(1 + \epsilon)$:
1207: 
1208: $$
1209: \zeta \approx -\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}
1210: $$
1211: 
1212: The erfc function satisfies $\text{erfc}(0) = 1$, and near $\zeta = 0$:
1213: 
1214: $$
1215: \text{erfc}(\zeta) \approx 1 - \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\zeta + O(\zeta^2)
1216: $$
1217: 
1218: Thus:
1219: 
1220: $$
1221: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} \approx \frac{1}{\tau_*(1+\epsilon)}\left[\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}}\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}\right]
1222: $$
1223: 
1224: Expanding for small $\epsilon$:
1225: 
1226: $$
1227: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} \approx \frac{1}{\tau_*}\left[1 - \epsilon + \frac{\sqrt{2}v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{\pi C_\sigma d(x)}}\epsilon\right] = \frac{v_n}{d(x)}\left[1 + O(\epsilon)\right]
1228: $$
1229: 
1230: Since $\epsilon = O(\Delta\tau/\tau_*) = O(\tau^{1/2})$, we conclude:
1231: 
1232: $$
1233: \left|\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) - c(x,v)\right| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau}
1234: $$
1235: 
1236: Integrating over the boundary layer:
1237: 
1238: $$
1239: |E_{1,\text{bd}}| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau} \int_{\mathcal{T}_\delta} f^\tau(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau} \cdot M_f \cdot |\mathcal{T}_\delta|
1240: $$
1241: 
1242: where $|\mathcal{T}_\delta|$ is the measure of the boundary layer.
1243: 
1244: **Combining the Bounds**
1245: 
1246: $$
1247: |E(\tau)| \le |E_1(\tau)| + |E_2(\tau)| \le C_1 M_f |\mathcal{T}_\delta| \sqrt{\tau} + \frac{M_v}{\delta} \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}
1248: $$
1249: 
1250: Setting $C := \max(C_1 M_f |\mathcal{T}_\delta|, M_v/\delta)$ gives:
1251: 
1252: $$
1253: |E(\tau)| \le C\left(\sqrt{\tau} + \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}\right)
1254: $$
1255: 
1256: **Note**: The $\sqrt{\tau}$ error arises from the Gaussian tail approximation in the drift-dominated regime. While the pointwise limit is exact (ballistic $v_n/d(x)$), the convergence rate is limited by the width of the transition region $\sim O(\tau^{1/2})$. This is the correct convergence rate for BAOAB with $O(\tau^{3/2})$ position noise.

1206: where $\zeta = (d(x) - v_n\tau)/(\sqrt{2C_\sigma}\tau^{3/2})$. For $\tau = \tau_*(1 + \epsilon)$:
1207: 
1208: $$
1209: \zeta \approx -\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}
1210: $$
1211: 
1212: The erfc function satisfies $\text{erfc}(0) = 1$, and near $\zeta = 0$:
1213: 
1214: $$
1215: \text{erfc}(\zeta) \approx 1 - \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\zeta + O(\zeta^2)
1216: $$
1217: 
1218: Thus:
1219: 
1220: $$
1221: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} \approx \frac{1}{\tau_*(1+\epsilon)}\left[\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}}\epsilon\frac{v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{2C_\sigma d(x)}}\right]
1222: $$
1223: 
1224: Expanding for small $\epsilon$:
1225: 
1226: $$
1227: \frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}} \approx \frac{1}{\tau_*}\left[1 - \epsilon + \frac{\sqrt{2}v_n^{3/2}}{\sqrt{\pi C_\sigma d(x)}}\epsilon\right] = \frac{v_n}{d(x)}\left[1 + O(\epsilon)\right]
1228: $$
1229: 
1230: Since $\epsilon = O(\Delta\tau/\tau_*) = O(\tau^{1/2})$, we conclude:
1231: 
1232: $$
1233: \left|\frac{1}{\tau}p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) - c(x,v)\right| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau}
1234: $$
1235: 
1236: Integrating over the boundary layer:
1237: 
1238: $$
1239: |E_{1,\text{bd}}| \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau} \int_{\mathcal{T}_\delta} f^\tau(x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \le C_1 \sqrt{\tau} \cdot M_f \cdot |\mathcal{T}_\delta|
1240: $$
1241: 
1242: where $|\mathcal{T}_\delta|$ is the measure of the boundary layer.
1243: 
1244: **Combining the Bounds**
1245: 
1246: $$
1247: |E(\tau)| \le |E_1(\tau)| + |E_2(\tau)| \le C_1 M_f |\mathcal{T}_\delta| \sqrt{\tau} + \frac{M_v}{\delta} \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}
1248: $$
1249: 
1250: Setting $C := \max(C_1 M_f |\mathcal{T}_\delta|, M_v/\delta)$ gives:
1251: 
1252: $$
1253: |E(\tau)| \le C\left(\sqrt{\tau} + \|f^\tau - f\|_{L^1}\right)
1254: $$
1255: 
1256: **Note**: The $\sqrt{\tau}$ error arises from the Gaussian tail approximation in the drift-dominated regime. While the pointwise limit is exact (ballistic $v_n/d(x)$), the convergence rate is limited by the width of the transition region $\sim O(\tau^{1/2})$. This is the correct convergence rate for BAOAB with $O(\tau^{3/2})$ position noise.
1257:

1360: Let $(X_i^\tau(t), V_i^\tau(t))_{i=1}^N$ be the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics (see {prf:ref}`def-baoab-update-rule` for the kinetic integrator) with timestep $\tau$, and let:
1361: 
1362: $$
1363: f_N^\tau(t, x, v) := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta(x - X_i^\tau(t), v - V_i^\tau(t))
1364: $$
1365: 
1366: be the empirical density. Then, in the joint limit $N \to \infty, \tau \to 0$ with $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for $\alpha > 0$:
1367: 
1368: $$
1369: f_N^\tau(t, \cdot, \cdot) \xrightarrow{\text{weak}} f(t, \cdot, \cdot)
1370: $$
